Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I glance at my phone as I step out of the polling station line, reading a text from my wife: “Rough day, just want to talk when you’re home.” I can hear her voice in my head, tired but trying to sound casual. I want to be there for her, to listen and reassure her, like I promised I always would. But just then, the election official calls my name. There’s a problem with my registration, and if I want my vote to count, I have to fill out a provisional ballot form—right now, before the station closes in ten minutes. The official’s tone is firm, and I know the rules are strict. I feel the weight of civic duty pressing on me, the expectation to follow every instruction and make my voice heard. But my heart aches, knowing my wife is waiting, needing me. I stand frozen, torn between the pull of my promise to her and my responsibility as a voter, the clock ticking louder with every second.
